thread.title: Big plays propel Coshocton past New Lex
thread.title_full: Big plays propel Coshocton past New Lex

title: Big plays propel Coshocton past New Lex
text:
Big plays propel Coshocton past New Lex Jason West, Correspondent 12:46 a.m. EDT October 3, 2015 Buy Photo Coshocton junior Jake Fortney carries the ball Friday night as New Lexington senior Mitch Wycinski and sophomore Tanner Wollenberg move in for the tackle. Coshocton won 14-7. The Advocate, Michael Lehmkuhle/Tribune Fullscreen Buy Photo New Lexington senior Andrew Spicer can't hold onto a pass as Coshocton senior Jeremy Bresciani moves in for the tackle Friday during what would be New Lexington's last chance to score and tie the game in the 4th. Coshocton won 14-7. The Advocate, Michael Lehmkuhle/Tribune Fullscreen Buy Photo Lexington senior Andrew Spicer carries the ball Friday night as Coshocton junior Andrew Mason moves in for the tackle during Coshocton's 14-7 victory. The Advocate, Michael Lehmkuhle/Tribune Fullscreen Buy Photo New Lexington senior Andrew Spicer tries to brush off Coshocton junior Andrew Mason Friday night during Coshocton's 14-7 victory. The Advocate, Michael Lehmkuhle/Tribune Fullscreen Buy Photo New Lexington Quarterback junior Bradley Clapper passes the ball to senior Andrew Spicer Friday night during the team's 14-7 to Coshocton. You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide New Lexington senior Andrew Spicer can't hold onto a pass as Coshocton senior Jeremy Bresciani moves in for the tackle Friday during what would be New Lexington's last chance to score and tie the game in the 4th. Coshocton won 14-7. (Photo: Michael Lehmkuhle/Tribune) 1 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
COSHOCTON — Friday night’s showdown between Coshocton and New Lexington wound up coming down to just one thing — big plays. 
The Redskins (4-2) got a pair of 70-plus-yard scoring plays to grab a 14-7 victory over the visiting Panthers at Stewart Field. 
“I thought whenever we needed a big play tonight we got it,” CHS coach Jim Woodrum said. “It wasn’t just the scoring plays, but when we need a big first down or a big play on defense, we seemed to come up with it.” 
In a game that saw the total yardage nearly equal, New Lex (2-4) held a 230-222 edge in total offense, it was those two big plays that made the difference for the Redskins. 
“Hats off to them because they made the big plays when they needed them,” New Lex coach David Rupe said. “I couldn’t be more proud of the kids’ effort or the staff with the schemes we had coming in; we just didn’t execute at a couple crucial times.” 
Both teams were able to move the ball between the 20s in the first half, but couldn’t get on the board until late in the first half. 
The Panthers took advantage of some good field position, and Bradley Clapper capped a 6-play drive with a 3-yard touchdown run to make it 7-0 with just 1:19 left in the first half. 
“We talked before the kickoff that we didn’t want to give up a big play and give them momentum headed to the locker room,” Rupe said. “We just didn’t execute.” 
Coshocton’s special teams delivered, as Spencer McCrea fielded the ensuing kickoff and went 81 yards for a score to tie the game at 7-7 with 1:08 left in the half. 
“We told the kids before the game that we thought special teams would be big because of the weather,” Woodrum said. “Spencer hit it just right, and the back wedge did a great job of giving him a seam.” 
Things stayed knotted up until the fourth quarter when Coshocton got the eventual game-winning touchdown. 
On a second-and-9 call, Andrew Mason found Zach Michael wide open for a 70-yard score at the 8:08 mark. 
“Give New Lex a lot of credit because their kids played hard and they had a good plan,” Woodrum said. “Once again we just made a play when we needed it most.” 
The teams traded punts before the Panthers had one last chance to tie the game. 
The Panthers drove from their own 20 to the Coshocton 28 in the final three minutes, but a fourth-and-8 pass fell incomplete with 30 seconds left to end it. 
“This was a tough one to swallow because I felt like we just didn’t finish drives,” Rupe said. “We have a young group and they gave great effort, but we just have to take advantage of opportunities when they are there.” 
Jake Fortney had 57 yards to lead Coshocton’s 129-yard rushing effort while Mason tossed for 93 yards through the air. 
New Lex got a solid performance from Clapper, who ran for 75 yards and threw for 153. 1 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://ohne.ws/1RlIoIf TOP VIDEOS
